bibl.title: Letter from Robert Wilson, Jr., to Hagood, Rivers, and Young, September 30, 1916

div1.p: Wilson relates findings that timbering in the Little Salkehatchie did not increase prevalence of malaria.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Wilson, Jr., to Hagood, Rivers, and Young, September 30, 1916
div1.opener:
Charleston, S.C.
Sept. 30, 1916.
Messrs. Hagood, Rivers & Young,
Charleston, S. C.
Dear Sirs:-
div1.p:
In response to your request I visited the
Little Salkehatchie Swamp on Sept. 8th, leaving Charleston
by automobile at six o'clock A.M. and arriving at Walter-
boro, a distance of about fifty-five miles, at eleven-
thirty, the long trip being due to an accident on the
road. From Walterboro I proceeded to the swamp in company
with Messrs. Frank and Hayne, and Dr. Cain of Charleston.
We spent about three hours at the swamp inspecting the
localities where cutting was in progress, others which had
been the sites of former cutting, and others again which
had never been cut. Dippings were made by Mr. Hayne at
a number of places in order to ascertain, if possible,
whether anopheles larvae were equally abundant in these
various localities.

The question to be answered, as I understand,
is whether or not the cutting of timber in the swamp could
have the effect of producing an increase in the prevalence
of malaria in the neighborhood adjacent. Inasmuch as
malaria is conveyed exclusively by mosquitoes of the
anopheles family, this question resolves itself into the
effect which the cutting of timber might have upon the
anopheles mosquitoes.

It is possible for felled timber to obstruct the
flow of water in such a way as to lead to the formation
of pools and so increase the number of breeding places.
Whether this condition really was produced is a matter
for observation to determine, and my inspection failed to
- 2 -
show that such an increase in breeding places actually
occurred. Furthermore, the opening up of the cut areas
to the freer action of air and sunshie would tend to
increase evaporation, and hasten the drying up of shallow
pools.

If the cutting brought about an increase in the
prevalence of malaria, we ought to find anopheles larvae
in greater abundance where the cutting was done. The
dippings made at the time of my visit, however, did not
show a large number of larvae anywhere, and there was
practically no difference in the numbers found in the
various localities examined. The conditions observed
generally near the houses in which malaria is said to
have been reported suggested that the breeding places might
be abundant in the immediate neighborhood of such houses,
and a careful survey should be made with the view of
determining if this be the case. It is significant and
suggestive that anopheles larvae were found in a branch
quite near the house of Mr. Allen Padgett in which I was
told several cases had developed.
